*   **Herbal remedies aur supplements:** Yeh hamesha safe nahi hote aur inke effects pregnancy par theek se study nahi kiye gaye hote. Doctor se pooche bina kuch mat lena.

**Sabse zaroori baat:**
Bhai, apni gynecologist se baat karna sabse best option hai. Unhe apni saari symptoms batao. Woh aapki pregnancy ki history aur current situation ko samajhkar hi aapko sabse safe aur effective tareeka batayenge.

Tab tak, rest karo, garam cheezein piyo aur garam kapde pehno. Apni aur baby ki sehat ka khayal rakho!

prompt_text:
Okay, here's the prompt:

Mujhe second trimester chal raha hai aur sardi-khansi ho gayi hai. Koi safe cold medications hain jo main le sakti hoon, batao na? Mujhe tension ho rahi hai!
model_response:
हाँ जी, बिलकुल समझ सकती हूँ आपकी चिंता। प्रेग्नेंसी में, खासकर जब सर्दी-खांसी हो जाए, तो मन में बहुत सवाल आते हैं कि क्या लेना सुरक्षित है और क्या नहीं। लेकिन घबराने की कोई बात नहीं है, सेकंड ट्राइमेस्टर में सर्दी-खांसी होना आम बात है।

सबसे पहले और सबसे ज़रूरी बात, **कोई भी दवाई लेने से पहले अपनी डॉक्टर (गायनेकोलॉजिस्ट) से ज़रूर सलाह लें।** वो आपकी पूरी कंडीशन, आपकी प्रेग्नेंसी की स्टेज और आपकी हेल्थ हिस्ट्री देखकर ही आपको सबसे सुरक्षित और सही दवाई बता पाएंगी। प्रेग्नेंसी में हर दवाई का असर अलग हो सकता है, इसलिए सेल्फ-मेडिकेशन बिल्कुल भी न करें।

तब तक, आप कुछ घरेलू उपाय अपना सकती हैं जिनसे आपको थोड़ा आराम मिल सकता है, और ये आमतौर पर सुरक्षित होते हैं:

1.  **खूब आराम करें:** शरीर को रिकवर होने के लिए आराम की बहुत ज़रूरत होती है।
2.  **गरम पानी पिएँ:** दिन भर थोड़ा-थोड़ा गरम पानी पीते रहें। इससे गले को आराम मिलता है और डिहाइड्रेशन नहीं होता। आप चाहें तो इसमें थोड़ा शहद (अगर आपको जेस्टेशनल डायबिटीज न हो) और नींबू भी मिला सकती हैं।
3.  **नमक वाले गरम पानी से गरारे:** गले की खराश और दर्द के लिए यह बहुत असरदार और सुरक्षित उपाय है।
4.  **भाप लें (स्टीम इनहेलेशन):** गरम पानी की भाप लेने से बंद नाक खुलती है और गले को आराम मिलता है। आप सादे पानी की भाप ले सकती हैं।
5.  **शहद:** खांसी के लिए शहद एक बहुत अच्छा और प्राकृतिक उपाय है। आप इसे सीधे ले सकती हैं या गरम पानी में मिलाकर।
6.  **सर को थोड़ा ऊँचा रखकर सोएँ:** सोते समय एक-दो तकिए लगाकर सर को थोड़ा ऊँचा रखने से रात में खांसी और नाक बंद होने की परेशानी कम हो सकती है।
7.  **गरम सूप या शोरबा:** गरम सूप पीने से भी गले को आराम मिलता है और शरीर को पोषण भी मिलता है।

याद रखिएगा, बिना डॉक्टर की सलाह के कोई भी ओवर-द-काउंटर (OTC) दवाई न लें, क्योंकि कई दवाओं में ऐसे तत्व हो सकते हैं जो प्रेग्नेंसी में सुरक्षित नहीं होते।

अपनी डॉक्टर से मिलें और वो आपको सही गाइडेंस देंगी। जल्दी ही आप ठीक हो जाएँगी! अपना ध्यान रखिए।

prompt_text: Yaar, I'm pregnant, aur mujhe thanda laga hai. Can I take safe cold medications during my second trimester, please? Koi problem toh nahi hoga na?
model_response:
Aww yaar, I can totally understand! Pregnancy mein thanda lagna is no fun at all, especially jab you're already feeling so much. Second trimester mein ho, that's good, but even then, medications ko lekar bohot careful rehna padta hai. **Koi problem toh nahi hoga na?** Iss sawal ka jawab sirf aur sirf aapke doctor hi sahi de sakte hain.

**Sabse pehle aur sabse zaroori baat, my dear: Please, please, please, apne gynaecologist se consult kiye bina koi bhi dawa mat lena.** Your doctor is the best person to tell you what's safe for *you* and your baby, because har pregnancy alag hoti hai, aur unhe aapki full medical history pata hoti hai.

Dekho, generally speaking, kuch cheezein hain jinse bachna chahiye ya doctor se pooch kar hi lena chahiye:

1.  **Decongestants (like Sudafed or those found in multi-symptom cold meds):** Oral decongestants often need to be avoided during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester, but even later, some doctors advise against them as they can sometimes affect blood pressure. Nasal sprays with decongestants bhi limited use ke liye hi hote hain.
2.  **NSAIDs (like Ibuprofen/Brufen, Naproxen):** Ye generally pregnancy mein avoid karne ko bolte hain, especially third trimester mein, but even second trimester mein, it's a big no-no without a doctor's explicit approval.
3.  **Multi-symptom cold medications:** In mein bohot saare ingredients hote hain, aur ho sakta hai aapko un sabki zaroorat na ho. Better to treat individual symptoms with doctor-approved meds.
4.  **Herbal remedies:** Log sochte hain natural hai toh safe hoga, but aisa nahi hai. Kuch herbs pregnancy mein harmful ho sakte hain. Always check with your doctor.

Agar doctor allow karein, toh kuch cheezein hain jo generally safer maani jaati hain for symptomatic relief, but again, **only with their go-ahead**:

*   **Paracetamol (Acetaminophen):** Fever ya body aches ke liye generally safe maana jaata hai, but dosage aur frequency doctor se confirm karna zaroori hai.
*   **Saline nasal sprays/rinses:** Congestion ke liye bohot effective aur safe hote hain, kyunki in mein koi medicinal ingredient nahi hota.
*   **Throat lozenges/gargles:** Sore throat ke liye, generally safe hain, but check ingredients for any medicinal components. Saltwater gargles are excellent and super safe!
*   **Cough syrups:** Kuch cough syrups (like those with Dextromethorphan or Guaifenesin) doctor approve kar sakte hain short-term use ke liye, but *never* self-medicate.

**Meanwhile, jab tak aap doctor ke paas jaati ho, kuch non-medicinal cheezein hain jo aapko relief degi aur totally safe hain:**

*   **Rest, rest, and more rest!** Apne body ko heal hone ka time do.
*   **Lots of fluids:** Warm water, soups, clear broths, ginger tea (moderate amount), nimbu paani, honey with warm water – hydration is key!
*   **Humidifier:** Dry air se throat aur nasal passages ko irritation ho sakti hai. Humidifier use karo.
*   **Elevate your head:** Sote waqt thoda head up rakhogi toh breathing easy hogi.
*   **Warm compress:** Sinus congestion ke liye face par warm compress rakh sakti ho.

Yaar, I know it's frustrating, but remember, aapki aur aapke baby ki safety sabse important hai. Ek call ya visit apne gynaecologist ko zaroor karna. Woh hi aapko sahi guidance de payenge. Get well soon, dear!

prompt_text:
Okay, here's the prompt, keeping in mind I am a man and speaking in standard English:

I am a guy, and I spearheaded a senior developer-led project that resulted in a 20% revenue increase. I need a formal, professional prompt to request a salary raise from my manager, highlighting my contributions and the project's success.
model_response:
Alright, man, that's a solid win you've got under your belt – a 20% revenue bump from a project you spearheaded with senior devs? That's the kind of tangible impact that speaks volumes. You absolutely deserve to highlight that and discuss your compensation.

Here's a formal and professional prompt you can adapt to request that meeting with your manager, along with some practical, safety-first advice to help you prepare.

---

### **Formal Email Prompt for Requesting a Meeting**

**Subject: Meeting Request: Discussion on Compensation – [Your Name]**

Dear [Manager's Name],

I hope this email finds you well.

I am writing to formally request a meeting to discuss my current compensation and salary.

Over the past [e.g., year, several months], I've been dedicated to contributing to [Company Name]'s strategic goals, and I believe my recent efforts have significantly impacted our financial success, warranting a review of my current salary.

Specifically, I am very proud of my leadership in spearheading the [**Name of Project, or brief description like "Q3 Revenue Growth Initiative"**] project. This was a complex initiative, involving our senior development team, which successfully concluded by generating a demonstrable **20% increase in revenue** for the company. I believe my commitment and leadership were instrumental in achieving this outstanding result.

I would appreciate the opportunity to sit down with you at your earliest convenience to discuss my contributions further and explore a salary adjustment that reflects my value and impact to both the team and the organization.

Please let me know what time works best for your schedule.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

Sincerely,

[Your Name]

---

### **Practical, Safety-First Advice for Your Salary Discussion**

Sending the email is just the first step. To ensure you're fully prepared and maximize your chances of success, here are a few things to keep in mind:

1.  **Do Your Homework (Market Research):** Before you even step into that meeting, know your worth. Research typical salary ranges for a developer with your experience, skills, and impact in your geographic area and industry. Websites like Glassdoor, LinkedIn Salary, and Levels.fyi can be great resources. This gives you a solid benchmark.

2.  **Document *Everything* Else:** While the 20% revenue increase is huge, don't stop there. List other achievements, responsibilities you've taken on beyond your core duties, positive feedback you've received, and any new skills you've acquired. The more data points you have, the stronger your case.

3.  **Prepare Your Talking Points:** Think about how you'll articulate your value beyond just the project. Practice what you'll say. Focus on quantifiable results and how your work directly benefits the company.

4.  **Anticipate Questions/Objections:** Your manager might ask about your career goals, what you feel a fair salary is, or even push back on the timing. Think about how you'd respond to these. For instance, if asked about a number, it's often good to state a range based on your research.

5.  **Be Professional, Always:** Maintain a confident but respectful tone throughout the discussion. Even if the initial answer isn't exactly what you hoped for, keep the conversation constructive. There might be a path forward (e.g., a raise in a few months, a promotion track).

6.  **Consider Timing:** While your recent success makes now a good time, be mindful of company-wide performance, budget cycles, or any major organizational changes that might impact the discussion.

7.  **Know Your "Walk Away" Point (But Don't Threaten):** It's good to know, internally, what you would consider an unacceptable offer. However, never *threaten* to leave. Frame it as what you believe your value is, and what you're looking for to continue contributing at a high level.

You've got a fantastic achievement to leverage, my man. Go in prepared, confident, and articulate, and you'll be in a great position. Good luck!

prompt_text:
Okay, here's the prompt, keeping in mind the instructions:

As a woman, I'm hoping you can help me prepare some talking points. I spearheaded a senior dev project that resulted in a 20% revenue increase for the company. I want to ask for a raise, but I need some help structuring my request and highlighting my accomplishments effectively.
model_response:
Oh, my dear! That is absolutely incredible! Spearheading a project that results in a **20% revenue increase** is a monumental achievement and speaks volumes about your talent, dedication, and leadership. You have every right to ask for a raise, and I'm so glad you're taking this step to advocate for yourself. Let's get these talking points polished so you can walk into that meeting feeling confident and prepared.

Here’s a practical, step-by-step approach to structuring your request and highlighting your accomplishments, with some safety-first considerations woven in:

### **Phase 1: Your Homework & Preparation (Before the Meeting)**

This is where you build your fortress of facts!

1.  **Quantify *Everything* (You've got the big one!):**
    *   You already have the golden nugget: "20% revenue increase." Be ready to state this clearly and confidently.
    *   **Safety First:** Gather any supporting data, reports, or emails that validate this number. If there's a specific report showing the revenue before and after, have it accessible (even if just for your own confidence).
    *   Think about *how* you achieved it. Did you optimize a process? Lead a team? Implement a new technology? Be ready to briefly explain the "how."

2.  **Research Your Market Value:**
    *   **Safety First:** This is crucial. Use sites like Glassdoor, LinkedIn Salary, Salary.com, or even professional recruiters to understand the typical salary range for a Senior Dev with your experience, skills, and – *critically* – your level of impact (revenue generation!) in your geographic area.
    *   Aim for a specific number you want, not a range. If you state a range, they'll likely go for the lower end. Your number should be well-justified by your research and your direct impact.

3.  **Document Your Contributions:**
    *   **Safety First:** Beyond the revenue, list all your contributions to this project:
        *   **Leadership:** "Spearheaded," "led a team of X," "mentored junior devs."
        *   **Problem-Solving:** What challenges did you overcome? How did you innovate?
        *   **Impact beyond revenue:** Did it improve efficiency? Customer satisfaction? Reduce costs elsewhere?
        *   Any positive feedback you received during the project.

4.  **Practice Your Pitch (Out Loud!):**
    *   It might feel a little silly, but practicing helps you sound smooth and confident. Rehearse your key points until they feel natural.

### **Phase 2: The Meeting Talking Points (Your Time to Shine!)**

Book a dedicated meeting, not a quick chat. Frame it as a "discussion about my career growth and compensation."

---

**1. Opening (Positive & Forward-Looking):**
*   "Thank you for taking the time to meet with me today. I'm really excited about the work I'm doing here at [Company Name] and my contributions to our recent successes."
*   "I particularly wanted to discuss my role in the [Project Name] initiative and how my contributions align with my career growth and compensation."

**2. Highlighting Your Accomplishment (The Core of Your Ask):**
*   **Start with your lead role:** "As the lead for the [Project Name] senior dev project..."
*   **State the impact immediately and clearly:** "...I'm incredibly proud that this initiative directly resulted in a **20% increase in company revenue** for [mention specific period, e.g., Q3, the last fiscal year]."
*   **Briefly explain the "how" (show your expertise):** "This was achieved through [mention 1-2 key strategies, e.g., 'optimizing our backend architecture to handle increased user load,' or 'developing a new feature that significantly improved conversion rates,' or 'streamlining our deployment process to accelerate time-to-market']."
*   **Connect it to company goals:** "This directly aligns with our company's strategic goals of [e.g., market growth, increasing profitability, expanding our user base]."
*   **Reinforce your leadership and initiative:** "My leadership in this project involved [e.g., 'managing a cross-functional team of X engineers,' 'overcoming Y technical challenges through Z solution,' 'ensuring on-time and on-budget delivery of critical milestones']."

**3. The Ask (Clear & Confident):**
*   "Given this significant, quantifiable contribution and my continued commitment to driving results and taking on leadership roles, I believe my current compensation no longer fully reflects my impact and market value."
*   "Based on my research into industry standards for a Senior Developer with my experience and proven ability to directly generate substantial revenue, I am requesting a salary of **[Your Specific Number]**." (Or, "I am requesting a **[X%]** raise to reflect my contributions.")

**4. Listening & Discussing (Be Prepared):**
*   After you state your request, pause and let them respond.
*   Be ready to reiterate your points with confidence if they push back or ask for more justification. "As I mentioned, the 20% revenue increase was a direct result of this project, which I spearheaded..."

---

### **Phase 3: Handling Responses & Follow-Up (Safety Net!)**

**If they say YES!**
*   Wonderful! Express your thanks and enthusiasm.
*   **Safety First:** Politely ask for the offer in writing, including the new salary, effective date, and any other agreed-upon terms. Don't assume anything until you see it on paper.

**If they say "Let me think about it" or "I need to discuss this with X":**
*   "I understand. What are the next steps in this process, and when can I expect to hear back from you?"
*   **Safety First:** Get a clear timeline. If they don't follow up by that date, send a polite reminder.

**If they say NO (or "not right now"):**
*   **Safety First:** Don't get discouraged immediately, but be prepared to pivot.
*   "I understand. Can you help me understand what specific metrics, achievements, or skills would be needed for me to earn this raise in the future? What's a realistic timeline for re-evaluating my compensation?" (This sets clear goals for you and holds them accountable.)
*   **Consider alternatives:** "Are there other ways we can recognize this significant contribution? Perhaps a performance bonus, additional professional development opportunities, a title change to reflect my leadership, or increased PTO?"
*   **Safety First:** If the company consistently undervalues you despite clear, quantifiable impact, it might be time to consider if this is the right place for your long-term career growth. You've proven your worth!

**After the Meeting:**
*   **Safety First:** Always send a polite thank-you email, briefly reiterating your key points (especially the 20% revenue increase!) and any agreed-upon next steps. This creates a paper trail.

You've done the hard work, my dear. You've delivered significant value. Now it's time to confidently ask for the recognition you deserve. You've got this!

prompt_text:
Here's a prompt for an LLM chatbot, tailored for the specified persona and instructions:

I am a person who was the senior developer on a project that resulted in a 20% revenue increase. I would like to initiate a conversation about my compensation.
model_response:
That's an excellent position to be in, and a 20% revenue increase is a truly significant achievement as a senior developer. It speaks volumes about your impact and leadership. Initiating a conversation about compensation from such a strong foundation is a smart and well-deserved move.

To ensure this conversation is as effective and beneficial for you as possible, let's approach it with careful preparation and a clear strategy. Think of this as laying the groundwork to articulate your value and secure the recognition you've earned.

Here are some practical, safety-first steps to consider before you initiate that conversation:

1.  **Quantify Your Impact (Beyond the 20%):** You have a fantastic headline number. Now, let's add depth.
    *   **How did *your specific contributions* directly lead to that 20%?** Break it down: new features, performance improvements, architectural decisions, mentoring, problem-solving, risk mitigation?
    *   **What was the *return on investment* (ROI) of your work?** If the project cost X, and revenue increased by Y, what's that ratio?
    *   **What was the *scope* of the project?** Was it a major company initiative?
    *   **Did it save costs elsewhere?** Improved efficiency, reduced bugs, less maintenance?
    *   **Future impact:** How does your work position the company for future growth or stability?

2.  **Research Market Value:** Before asking, know what someone with your skills, experience, and proven impact should be earning in your location and industry.
    *   Utilize sites like Glassdoor, Levels.fyi, LinkedIn Salary, and industry-specific salary surveys.
    *   Look for roles with similar responsibilities and impact, not just job titles.
    *   Consider the total compensation package (base salary, bonus, equity, benefits).

3.  **Define Your "Ask":** What exactly are you seeking?
    *   A specific salary increase?
    *   A promotion to a higher title with corresponding compensation?
    *   A performance bonus directly tied to the project's success?
    *   Increased equity or stock options?
    *   Be clear and precise with your desired outcome. Have a target range rather than a single number, allowing for negotiation.

4.  **Identify Your Audience and Timing:**
    *   **Who is the right person to speak with?** Usually your direct manager, possibly HR, or a combination.
    *   **When is the best time?** After a successful project launch, before annual review cycles (if possible), or when the company is doing well financially. Avoid peak busy periods or times of company stress.

5.  **Prepare Your Talking Points (and Practice!):**
    *   **Opening:** "I'd like to schedule some time to discuss my compensation and career growth, particularly in light of the recent success of [Project Name]."
    *   **Highlight your achievements:** Start with the 20% revenue increase, then elaborate on your specific contributions and their value. Use data and specific examples.
    *   **Connect to market value:** "Based on my impact and current market rates for someone with my experience and proven ability to drive revenue, I believe my compensation should reflect X."
    *   **Listen and be ready to discuss:** Be prepared for questions, potential pushback, or requests for more information.
    *   **Focus on value, not just time:** Frame your discussion around the value you bring and the results you deliver, rather than simply time served.

6.  **Anticipate Potential Responses:**
    *   **"Yes, let's do it!"** (Great!)
    *   **"Let me look into it."** (Follow up politely if you don't hear back within a reasonable timeframe.)
    *   **"The budget isn't there right now."** (Ask what metrics or timelines would make it possible in the future, or explore non-monetary benefits like professional development, more autonomy, or a clearer path to promotion.)
    *   **"Your current compensation is fair."** (Be ready to reiterate your data points and market research.)

7.  **Document Everything:** Keep a personal record of your achievements, the conversation date, who you spoke with, what was discussed, and any agreed-upon next steps. This is your professional safety net.

By taking these steps, you're not just asking for more money; you're presenting a compelling business case for investing further in a high-performing asset (you!). This proactive and data-driven approach significantly increases your chances of a successful outcome.

How does this sound as a starting point? Are there any specific aspects you'd like to dive into first, like researching market value or structuring your talking points?

prompt_text: Bhai, main senior dev hoon, ek project lead kiya jisne 20% revenue boost diya. Ab mujhe raise chahiye, kaise baat karoon boss se? Kuch suggestion hai kya?
model_response:
Arre Bhai, bohot badhiya! 20% revenue boost? Yeh toh *zabardast* kaam kiya hai tune! Senior dev hone ke naate, aur itna impact laane ke baad, raise maangna tera poora haq banta hai. Chinta mat kar, main batata hoon kaise approach karega.

Dekh, boss se raise maangna koi bheek maangna nahi hai, yeh ek business discussion hai jahaan tu apni value prove kar raha hai. Toh confidence se jaa, yaar!

Yahaan kuch practical suggestions hain, bilkul step-by-step:

1.  **Poori Taiyaari Kar Le (Homework is Key!):**
    *   **Apna Impact Number Pakka Kar:** Jo tune bataya na, 20% revenue boost, isko bilkul pakka kar le. Kaise calculate hua, kab se kab tak, kitna amount banta hai – yeh saari details tere paas honi chahiye. Sirf revenue hi nahi, kya tune koi process optimize kiya, team members ko mentor kiya, ya koi critical bug fix kiya jisse downtime bacha? Woh bhi mention kar.
    *   **Market Research:** Dekh, tere role aur experience ke hisaab se market mein kya salary chal rahi hai? LinkedIn, Glassdoor, Naukri jaise platforms pe check kar le. Isse tujhe ek range mil jaayegi jisse tu apni demand justify kar paayega. Yeh dikhaata hai ki tu sirf hawa mein baat nahi kar raha.
    *   **Apni "Ask" Decide Kar:** Tu kitni raise chahta hai? Ek specific figure (e.g., 20% increase) ya ek range (e.g., 15-25% increase) apne mind mein set kar le. Hamesha thoda higher side pe soch, taaki negotiation ki gunjaish rahe.

2.  **Sahi Samay aur Sahi Jagah Choose Kar:**
    *   **Boss Ka Mood Dekh:** Jab boss thoda free ho, good mood mein ho, aur unke paas sunne ka time ho, tab baat kar. Project deadlines ya company crisis ke time pe mat jaana.
    *   **Meeting Request Kar:** "Sir/Ma'am, kya hum thodi der baat kar sakte hain? Main apne recent project contributions aur career growth par discuss karna chahta hoon." Isse unko pata chal jaayega ki tu serious baat karna chahta hai aur woh time nikal paayenge.

3.  **Baat Kaise Kare (The Conversation Itself):**
    *   **Shuruat Achhi Kar:** "Sir/Ma'am, main aapka shukraguzar hoon ki mujhe [Project Name] lead karne ka mauka mila. Yeh mere liye ek fantastic experience raha."
    *   **Seedhe Mudde Par Aa, Data Ke Saath:** "Mujhe yeh batate hue khushi ho rahi hai ki meri lead kiye hue project ne company ke revenue mein direct **20% ka boost** diya hai, jo ki [specific amount] banta hai. Iske alawa, maine [other achievements, like team mentoring, process improvement] bhi kiya."
    *   **Apni Value Highlight Kar:** "Main maanta hoon ki mera contribution company ke liye significant raha hai aur main aage bhi aise hi impact create karna chahta hoon."
    *   **Apni Demand Rakho:** "Isi ke chalte, main aapke saath apni compensation discuss karna chahta hoon. Market research aur mere current impact ko dekhte hue, main [specific percentage/amount] ki raise expect kar raha hoon." Ya "Meri expectation hai ki meri salary [X amount] tak pahunche."
    *   **Future Contributions Par Focus Kar:** "Main aage bhi company ke growth mein contribute karne ke liye utsuk hoon aur maanta hoon ki yeh raise mere motivation aur commitment ko aur badhaayegi."
    *   **Sunne Ke Liye Taiyaar Reh:** Boss kya bolte hain, unki baat suno. Ho sakta hai woh kuch questions poochein ya counter offer dein. Calmly suno aur phir jawaab do.

4.  **Kya Ho Agar Turant 'Haan' Na Mile?**
    *   **Reason Puchh:** "Main samajhta hoon. Kya aap bata sakte hain ki current situation mein kya factors hain jo ismein rukawat ban rahe hain? Main un par kaam karne ke liye taiyaar hoon."
    *   **Alternative Options Explore Kar:** Agar raise nahi mil rahi, toh kya koi promotion ya title change mil sakta hai? Kya koi performance bonus mil sakta hai? Kya koi upskilling course ya conference sponsor ho sakti hai?
    *   **Follow-Up Plan:** "Theek hai. Toh kya hum [3-6 mahine] baad dobara is par baat kar sakte hain? Tab tak main [specific goals] par kaam karunga."

5.  **Safety-First Tips:**
    *   **Dhamki Mat Dena:** "Agar raise nahi mili toh main chhod dunga." Yeh approach bilkul galat hai aur backfire kar sakti hai. Professional reh.
    *   **Confident, Not Arrogant:** Tu apni value jaanta hai, use confidently present kar, arrogant banke nahi.
    *   **Document Everything:** Agar boss verbal commit karta hai, toh follow-up email mein use summarize kar de. "Sir/Ma'am, as discussed, I'm looking forward to the raise of X% by [date]..."

Bhai, tune itna mast kaam kiya hai, yeh toh pakka hai ki tu deserve karta hai. Bas sahi tareeke se apni baat rakh, poore data aur confidence ke saath. All the very best, mere bhai! Ja, phod de!

prompt_text:
Okay, here's a Hinglish prompt for an LLM chatbot, tailored to the user's intent, persona, and specific instructions:

Yaar, main ek senior dev thi, aur maine project lead kiya jisne company ko 20% revenue boost diya! Mujhe lagta hai ki ab mujhe meri salary increase milni chahiye. Iske baare mein kaise baat karun apne manager se, aur kya-kya points highlight karun?
model_response:
Arre wah, yaar! Kya baat hai! Senior dev banke 20% revenue boost dilana company ko – yeh toh pakka raise deserve karta hai! Tumhara confidence bilkul sahi hai. Chalo, main batata hoon kaise smart tareeke se apne manager se baat karni hai, aur kya-kya points highlight karne hain.

**Pehle, Thoda Homework Kar Lo (Preparation is Key):**

1.  **Apne Achievements Quantify Karo:**
    *   **The Big One:** Jo project tumne lead kiya aur 20% revenue boost diya, uski saari details ready rakho. Kitne time mein hua? Tumhara exact role kya tha? Kya challenges aaye aur tumne unhe kaise solve kiya? Numbers aur percentages bahut impact karte hain.
    *   **Other Contributions:** Iske alawa tumne aur kya-kya kiya hai? Kya kisi junior ko mentor kiya? Koi naya process implement kiya jisse efficiency badhi? Koi critical bug fix kiya? Sab likh lo.
    *   **Responsibilities:** Kya tumhari responsibilities badhi hain over time? Kya tum senior dev ke roles ke alawa bhi kuch extra kaam kar rahe ho?
2.  **Market Research Karo:**
    *   **Apni Value Jaano:** Dekho ki industry mein, tumhare experience aur skills ke saath, similar roles ke liye kitni salary mil rahi hai. LinkedIn, Glassdoor, Naukri jaise platforms pe check karo. Isse tumhe ek realistic figure milega aur tum confident rahoge.
3.  **Target Figure Set Karo:**
    *   Ek specific amount ya percentage ka raise apne mind mein rakho. Aur ek 'range' bhi bana lo – minimum kitna chahiye aur ideal kitna hoga.

**Manager Se Kaise Baat Karein (How to Talk to Your Manager):**

1.  **Meeting Request Karo, Casual Chat Nahi:**
    *   Ek proper meeting schedule karo. Email ya message mein likho ki "I'd like to schedule a dedicated time to discuss my career progression, performance, and compensation." Casual coffee break mein yeh baat mat karna.
    *   Meeting ka time thoda lamba rakho (30-45 mins), taaki aaraam se baat ho sake.
2.  **Meeting Ke Dauran (During the Meeting):**
    *   **Positive Aur Confident Raho:** Smile ke saath shuru karo. Unhe thank karo meeting ke liye.
    *   **Apne Contributions Highlight Karo:**
        *   **Start with the Big Win:** "Sir/Ma'am, pichle X samay mein, maine [Project Name] ko lead kiya, jiske result mein company ko 20% revenue boost mila. Ismein maine [apni specific actions] kiye, jiski wajah se [outcome]." Poora focus impact pe rakho.
        *   **Link to Company Goals:** Batao ki tumhara kaam company ke overall goals se kaise align karta hai.
        *   **Beyond Code:** "Sirf coding hi nahi, maine [mentorship, process improvement, problem-solving] mein bhi contribute kiya hai."
    *   **Market Value Discuss Karo (Agar Relevant Lage):**
        *   "Maine industry standards research kiye hain, aur meri skills aur experience ke hisaab se, current market mein [X amount/range] salary common hai."
    *   **Future Value Dikhana:**
        *   "Main aage bhi company ke liye aur value add karna chahta hoon. Mere paas [nayi ideas ya future projects] hain jinmein main contribute kar sakta hoon."
        *   Yeh dikhata hai ki tum sirf past achievements pe nahi, future commitment pe bhi focus kar rahe ho.
    *   **Apni Specific Request Rakho:**
        *   "In sab contributions aur market value ko dekhte hue, I would like to request a salary increase to [Your Target Figure]."
    *   **Sunne Ke Liye Ready Raho:**
        *   Manager ki baat suno. Ho sakta hai unke paas questions hon ya unhe thoda time chahiye ho.
        *   Agar woh negotiate karein, toh tum bhi ready raho.
    *   **Safety First:**
        *   **Ultimatum Mat Dena:** "Agar raise nahi mila toh main chhod dunga" – yeh approach avoid karo. Yeh unprofessional lagta hai.
        *   **Emotional Mat Hona:** Facts aur figures pe stick karo, emotional arguments se bachho.
        *   Agar immediate 'no' milta hai, toh poochho ki **"What specific goals or achievements would I need to demonstrate in the next 3-6 months to be eligible for a raise?"** Isse tumhe clear roadmap mil jaayega.

3.  **Follow-up (Meeting Ke Baad):**
    *   Meeting ke baad ek thank you email bhej do, jismein main discussion points aur apne achievements brief mein summarise kar do. Isse sab record mein rahega.
    *   Agar manager ne bola ki woh time lenge, toh poochho ki kab tak tum expect kar sakte ho ek update.

Yaad rakhna, tumne company ke liye bahut bada impact create kiya hai. Apni value ko confidently present karo. All the best, yaar! Mujhe poora yakeen hai ki tum yeh handle kar loge!

prompt_text: Boss, maine ek senior dev team lead kari, project launch successful hua, aur revenue 20% se badh gaya! Ab mujhe salary badhane ki baat karni hai, kaise shuru karun?
model_response:
Bahut khoob! Sun kar bahut khushi hui. Yeh toh kamaal kar diya tumne! Ek senior dev team lead karna, project launch successful karana, aur revenue mein 20% ka jump dena – yeh sab show karta hai ki tumne company ke liye real value add ki hai. Aisi performance ke baad salary increment ki baat karna bilkul sahi hai.

Chalo, main tumhe kuch practical aur safety-first tips deta hoon ki kaise shuru karna hai:

### **1. Apna Case Strong Banao (Data, Data, Data!)**

Salary badhane ki baat karne se pehle, apna homework acche se kar lo.
*   **Quantify Your Achievements:**
    *   **Revenue Growth:** Jo 20% revenue increase hua hai, usko numbers mein convert karo. Agar tumhe exact figures pata hain, toh batao ki tumhare project ki wajah se company ko kitna *extra* revenue mila. Example: "Mere project ki wajah se company ka revenue X crore se badha."
    *   **Team Leadership:** Senior dev team ko lead karna koi choti baat nahi. Isme tumhari kya specific responsibilities thi? Kya tumne koi process improve kiya? Team ki efficiency badhai? Mentorship di? Isko bhi highlight karo.
    *   **Project Impact:** Project ne company ke liye aur kya fayde diye? Cost saving, efficiency increase, naye customers lana, market share badhana, brand value – jo bhi ho, usko numbers mein ya specific examples ke saath batao.
*   **Market Research:**
    *   Apni current role, experience, aur skill set ke hisaab se market mein kitni salary mil rahi hai, yeh pata karo. Glassdoor, LinkedIn, Naukri.com, ya industry contacts se research karo. Isse tumhe ek realistic salary range pata chalegi.
    *   Yeh research tumhe confidence degi aur tumhare ask ko justify karegi.

### **2. Sahi Samay Chuno (Timing is Key!)**

*   **Project Success Fresh Hai:** Abhi ka time bilkul perfect hai, kyunki project ki success aur uska impact abhi fresh hai sabke dimaag mein.
*   **Performance Review:** Agar tumhara annual performance review aane wala hai, toh usko use kar sakte ho. Warna, abhi ek alag meeting request karna bhi theek hai.

### **3. Meeting Request Kaise Karein**

*   **Manager se baat karo:** Apne direct manager ko ek email bhejo. Saaf-saaf batao ki tum kis baare mein baat karna chahte ho.
*   **Email Subject:** "Meeting Request: Career Development & Compensation Discussion" ya "Discussion on Project Success and Future Contributions."
*   **Email Body:**
    *   "Hi [Manager's Name],
    *   Umeed hai aap theek honge.
    *   Main aapke saath ek meeting schedule karna chahta hoon, jisme hum mere recent achievements, khaas kar ke [Project Name] project ki success aur uske revenue impact (20% growth) par discuss kar sakein. Main apne career development aur compensation ke baare mein bhi baat karna chahta hoon.
    *   Kripya mujhe batayein ki aapke liye kaun sa samay convenient rahega.
    *   Thanks,
    *   [Your Name]"
*   **Purpose Clear Rakho:** Email mein purpose clear rakhne se manager bhi prepare ho kar aayega, aur discussion productive hoga.

### **4. Meeting Ke Dauran (How to Present Your Case)**

*   **Start with Gratitude:** Meeting shuru karte waqt team aur opportunity ke liye shukriya karo.
*   **Present Your Achievements (with Numbers):**
    *   "Sir/Ma'am, jaisa ki aap jaante hain, maine [Project Name] project ko successfully lead kiya. Is project ki wajah se company ke revenue mein 20% ka इजाफा hua, jo ki approximately [Exact Amount] banta hai."
    *   "Iske alawa, maine senior dev team ko efficiently manage kiya, jisse humne [specific task] mein [X]% ki efficiency gain ki."
    *   "Yeh sab meri responsibilities se badhkar tha, aur maine isme extra effort daala."
*   **Connect to Future:** Sirf past ki baat nahi, future mein tum company ke liye aur kya kar sakte ho, yeh bhi batao. Tumhare naye skills aur experience company ko kaise aur fayda pahuncha sakte hain.
*   **State Your Ask (Confidently):**
    *   Apni desired salary range batao. Market research se jo range nikali hai, usko use karo.
    *   "Meri current responsibilities, market value, aur jo value maine company ko provide ki hai, uske hisaab se, main apni compensation ko [X amount] se [Y amount] ki range mein adjust karne ki request karta hoon."
    *   Ek exact figure dene ki bajaye range dena better hota hai, negotiation ke liye space milta hai.
*   **Listen and Negotiate:**
    *   Unki baat suno. Ho sakta hai woh immediate decision na le paayein.
    *   Pushy mat bano, but confident raho. Agar woh counter-offer dein, toh us par विचार karo.
    *   Agar cash increment possible na ho, toh other benefits (stock options, bonus, extra holidays, learning budget, better job title, work-from-home flexibility) par bhi baat kar sakte ho.

### **5. Safety-First/Strategic Guidance**

*   **Professional Raho, Emotional Nahi:** Apni baat facts aur figures par based rakho, na ki emotions par.
*   **Don't Threaten:** Kabhi bhi company chhodne ki dhamki mat do, jab tak tum seriously prepare na ho dusri job ke liye. Isse impression kharab hota hai.
*   **Be Prepared for "No":** Agar woh "no" kehte hain, toh reason poocho. Kya specific areas hain jahan tumhe aur improve karna hai? Next review tak ke liye ek clear plan banao ki tum kya achieve karoge.
*   **Document Everything:** Meeting ke baad, ek summary email bhejo apne manager ko, jisme discuss kiye gaye points aur next steps mention ho. Isse sab kuch documented rahega.

Tumne jo kiya hai, woh bahut badi baat hai. Confidently jao aur apni worth demand karo. Tumne company ke liye value add ki hai, aur ab time hai us value ko recognize karwane ka.

All the best, Champion! Mujhe poora yakeen hai ki tum yeh bhi handle kar loge.

prompt_text: I am a guy, and a colleague has been sending me inappropriate comments on WhatsApp. I need help figuring out how to address this situation. Can you suggest some options?
model_response:
Hey man, that sounds like a really tough and uncomfortable situation to be in. Nobody should have to deal with inappropriate comments from a colleague, especially not on their personal time or platform like WhatsApp. It's absolutely not okay, and it's important to remember that this isn't your fault.

Your comfort and safety are paramount here. Let's break down some practical options you have, moving from less formal to more formal, so you can pick what feels right for you.

**First, and most importantly: Document Everything.**
Before you do anything else, make sure you have a record.
*   **Screenshot all the messages:** Get clear screenshots of the inappropriate comments, making sure the date, time, and sender's name are visible.
*   **Note down details:** If there were any related incidents in person or elsewhere, jot down dates, times, and what happened. This creates a solid paper trail, which can be invaluable if you decide to take formal action.

**Now, let's look at your options for addressing it:**

1.  **Direct, Clear Communication (If you feel safe and comfortable):**
    If you feel safe enough to address it directly, a clear, firm message can sometimes put a stop to it.
    *   **What to say:** Something like: "Hey [Colleague's Name], I need you to stop sending me messages like this. They are inappropriate and make me uncomfortable. Please keep our communication strictly professional from now on."
    *   **Why this might work:** It sets a clear boundary immediately.
    *   **Caveat:** Only do this if you feel safe and confident that it won't escalate the situation in a negative way for you. If you have any doubt, skip this step.

2.  **Silence and Block/Mute:**
    If direct communication isn't an option, or if it doesn't work, you can control your exposure.
    *   **Block them on WhatsApp:** This will stop them from sending you messages directly.
    *   **Mute their notifications:** If blocking feels too drastic right away, muting them means you won't be constantly interrupted by their messages, giving you some mental space.
    *   **Why this might work:** It immediately stops the flow of inappropriate content to you and gives you some peace.
    *   **Caveat:** While it stops the messages, it doesn't address the underlying behavior at work, which might still need to be handled.

3.  **Talk to a Trusted Manager or HR (Informal Approach First):**
    This is often a good next step, especially if you don't feel comfortable addressing it directly or if it continues after you've tried.
    *   **Who to talk to:** Your direct manager (if you trust them and they're not the problem), or someone in HR.
    *   **What to say:** Explain what's happening, show them the screenshots, and state that these comments are making you uncomfortable and affecting your ability to work professionally. You can initially ask for advice or for them to have an informal word with the colleague.
    *   **Why this might work:** It brings the issue to the attention of leadership or HR, who are responsible for maintaining a safe work environment. They might be able to resolve it discreetly.

4.  **File a Formal Complaint with HR:**
    If the informal approach doesn't work, or if the comments are particularly egregious, a formal complaint is the way to go.
    *   **What to do:** Ask HR about the company's harassment policy and the formal complaint process. Submit a written complaint, attaching all your evidence (screenshots, notes).
    *   **Why this might work:** This initiates an official investigation, and the company is legally obligated to address it. There will be a formal record of your complaint.
    *   **Be prepared for:** An investigation process, which might involve interviews and potentially disciplinary action against the colleague.

**Important Considerations:**

*   **Company Policy:** Check your company's employee handbook or intranet for their specific policies on workplace harassment, conduct, and social media use. This will give you a clear understanding of your rights and the company's responsibilities.
*   **Your Well-being:** This kind of situation can be stressful. Lean on trusted friends, family, or even a therapist if you need to talk things through. Prioritize your mental and emotional health.
*   **Confidentiality:** When you speak to HR or a manager, ask about the confidentiality of the process. While they can't always guarantee absolute anonymity (especially if an investigation is required), they should be able to explain how they handle sensitive information.
*   **Retaliation:** Be aware of company policies regarding retaliation. It's illegal for an employer to retaliate against you for reporting harassment. If you experience any negative changes in your work environment after reporting, document those immediately too.

You're doing the right thing by seeking help and wanting to address this. Choose the path that feels safest and most effective for you. You have every right to a respectful and professional work environment.

prompt_text:
Okay, here's the prompt, keeping in mind the instructions:

I am a woman, and I need help. My colleague is making inappropriate comments to me on WhatsApp. Can you suggest *kya* I should do, *kya* options *hain* I have, and how I can handle this situation *without* escalating it unnecessarily? I am feeling very uncomfortable.
model_response:
Aapki baat sunkar bahut afsos hua, aur yeh bilkul theek nahi hai ki aapko aisi uncomfortable situation mein daala jaa raha hai. Aapki feelings bilkul valid hain, aur aapko isse deal karne ke liye options milne hi chahiye. Aapki safety aur comfort sabse pehle hain.

Chaliye, dekhte hain *kya* aap kar sakti hain, aur *kya* options *hain* aapke paas, bina baat ko *unnecessarily* badhaaye:

### **Sabse Pehla Kadam: Proof Ikatha Karein (Gather Evidence)**

Isse pehle ki aap kuch aur karein, yeh bahut zaroori hai:

1.  **Screenshots Le Lein:** Jo bhi inappropriate comments hain, un sabke screenshots le lein. Date aur time bhi dikhna chahiye. Yeh aapke paas proof rahega, chahe aap abhi use karein ya baad mein.
2.  **Baat Chit Ko Save Karein:** Agar WhatsApp chat export karne ka option hai, toh woh bhi kar lein.

Yeh steps bahut important hain, even if you don't want to escalate right now.

### **Options, Bina Zaroorat Se Zyaada Escalation Ke:**

**Option 1: Seedhe Aur Spasht Boundary Set Karein (Direct but Firm Communication)**

Agar aap comfortable hain, toh aap seedhe unse baat kar sakti hain. Ismein aapko bahut professional aur clear rehna hai:

*   **Ek Message Bhejein:** "Hi [Colleague's Name], main chahti hoon ki aapko pata chale ki aapke kuch comments mujhe uncomfortable kar rahe hain. Main chahti hoon ki humari conversations sirf professional topics tak hi seemit rahein."
*   **Tone:** Yeh message calm, firm aur professional hona chahiye. Blame ya emotion se bachna hai. Sirf fact batana hai ki aap uncomfortable hain aur aapko kya chahiye.
*   **Faida:** Kayi baar log anjaane mein ya bina soche-samjhe comments kar dete hain. Ek seedha message unhe realize karwa sakta hai aur woh ruk sakte hain.
*   **Nuksan (Potential):** Agar woh samajhdar nahi hain, toh ho sakta hai woh ignore karein ya aur bura behave karein. Isliye, screenshots pehle se hone chahiye.

**Option 2: Communication Channels Change Karein (Shift Communication Channels)**

*   **Work-Related Chats:** Agar unke comments work-related WhatsApp group mein nahi hain, toh unse kahein ki work-related baatein sirf official company email ya official chat platform par hi karein.
*   **Personal Chats Kam Karein:** Unke personal messages ka jawab dena band kar dein, ya bahut short aur formal reply dein. Unhe samjhayenge ki aap personal chats mein interested nahi hain.
*   **Faida:** Yeh unhe indirectly message dega ki aap sirf professional interaction chahti hain.
*   **Nuksan:** Ho sakta hai woh fir bhi try karein.

**Option 3: Unhe Block/Mute Karein (Block/Mute Them)**

*   **Mute:** Agar aap unhe WhatsApp par block nahi karna chahti, toh unki chat ko mute kar dein. Isse aapko unke messages ki notifications nahi aayengi aur aapko baar-baar unke comments dekhne nahi padenge.
*   **Block:** Agar unke comments bilkul bhi work-related nahi hain aur sirf personal/inappropriate hain, toh aap unhe block kar sakti hain.
*   **Faida:** Immediate relief milega, aur aapko unke messages se pareshaan nahi hona padega.
*   **Nuksan:** Agar work-related communication bhi WhatsApp par hoti hai, toh yeh option mushkil ho sakta hai. Aur, blocking se unhe pata chal jaayega ki aapne unhe block kiya hai, jo thoda awkward ho sakta hai office mein.

### **Agar Low-Escalation Options Kaam Na Karein Ya Aap Unhe Choose Na Karna Chahein:**

**Option 4: Kisi Bharosemand Co-worker Ya Senior Se Baat Karein (Talk to a Trusted Colleague/Senior)**

*   **Advice Ke Liye:** Aap kisi aise colleague ya senior se baat kar sakti hain jin par aapko bharosa hai. Unse sirf advice maangein ki aap is situation mein *kya* kar sakti hain. Ho sakta hai unhone pehle bhi aisi situation dekhi ho.
*   **Faida:** Aapko ek alag perspective milega aur aapko akela mehsoos nahi hoga.
*   **Nuksan:** Ensure karein ki woh insaan sach mein trustworthy hai, varna baat phail sakti hai.

**Option 5: HR Department Se Baat Karein (Talk to HR)**

Aapne kaha "unnecessarily escalate" nahi karna, lekin HR se baat karna tab zaroori ho jaata hai jab aapki comfort aur safety par baat aaye. Aap HR se is tarah baat kar sakti hain:

*   **Confidentiality Ki Request:** HR se request karein ki aap unse confidential tareeke se baat karna chahti hain, aur aap abhi koi formal complaint file nahi karna chahti, sirf advice aur options jaanna chahti hain.
*   **Situation Explain Karein:** Unhe screenshots dikhayein aur poori baat batayein.
*   **Faida:** HR department ka kaam employees ko safe rakhna hota hai. Woh aapko company policies ke baare mein bata sakte hain aur aapko proper channels ke through guide kar sakte hain. Woh aapki identity protect karte hue bhi action le sakte hain.
*   **Nuksan:** Ek baar HR involved ho jaaye, toh baat thodi official ho sakti hai. Lekin, yeh aapka right hai aur agar situation sudhar nahi rahi toh yeh ek zaroori kadam hai.

### **Kuch Aur Zaroori Baatein:**

*   **Apni Gut Feeling Par Bharosa Rakhein:** Agar aapko uncomfortable feel ho raha hai, toh woh theek nahi hai. Apne instincts ko follow karein.
*   **Professional Boundaries Rakhein:** Is colleague ke saath hamesha professional boundaries maintain karein, chahe woh WhatsApp ho ya office mein. Personal baaton se bachein.
*   **Aap Akeli Nahi Hain:** Yaad rakhiye, aap akeli nahi hain. Aapko support mil sakta hai.

Umeed hai yeh options aapki madad karenge. Aap apne hisaab se decide karein ki aapke liye sabse comfortable aur safe option *kya* hai. Aapki comfort aur respect sabse important hai.

prompt_text: I am receiving inappropriate comments from a colleague on WhatsApp. Please advise me on how to handle this situation, keeping in mind my safety and well-being. What are my options?
model_response:
Oh dear, I am so sorry to hear you're going through this difficult and unsettling experience. Receiving inappropriate comments from a colleague, especially on a personal platform like WhatsApp, is absolutely unacceptable and can be deeply distressing. Please know that your feelings are valid, and you have every right to feel safe and respected, both in and out of the workplace.

Your safety and well-being are the absolute priority here. Let's break down your options, focusing on practical, safety-first guidance.

### Immediate Steps (Prioritizing Your Safety and Evidence)

1.  **Do NOT Engage Further:** The most important thing right now is to *not* respond to the inappropriate messages. Engaging can sometimes escalate the situation or be misinterpreted.
2.  **Document Everything (Crucial Evidence):**
    *   **Take Screenshots:** Immediately take clear screenshots of *all* the inappropriate messages. Make sure the screenshots include:
        *   The full message content.
        *   The sender's name/contact information.
        *   The date and time of the messages.
    *   **Save the Chat History:** If WhatsApp allows, export the chat history for an additional record.
    *   **Keep a Log:** Create a personal log (on your computer, in a secure document) detailing:
        *   Dates and times of all incidents.
        *   Specific content of the inappropriate comments (even if you have screenshots, a summary can be helpful).
        *   Any other relevant details, like the context, your feelings, or any witnesses (if applicable).
    *   **Store Safely:** Store these screenshots and logs in a secure place, perhaps even backing them up to a cloud service or emailing them to yourself, so you have multiple copies.
3.  **Block the Colleague on WhatsApp:** Once you've secured the evidence, block this person on WhatsApp. This will prevent them from sending you any more messages through that platform.
    *   *How to block:* Open the chat with the colleague > Tap their name at the top > Scroll down and tap "Block."
4.  **Inform a Trusted Person:** Share what's happening with a trusted friend, family member, or partner. Not only will this provide you with emotional support, but it also creates an external witness who is aware of the situation.
5.  **Review Your Company's Policies:** Most companies have a clear anti-harassment policy, code of conduct, or respectful workplace policy. Locate this document (it's often in an employee handbook, on the company intranet, or available from HR) and familiarize yourself with the reporting procedures.

### Your Options for Addressing the Situation

Once you've secured the evidence and taken immediate safety steps, you have several avenues to pursue:

**Option 1: Formal Reporting Within Your Company**

This is often the most effective and recommended path for workplace-related harassment.

*   **Who to Report To:**
    *   **Human Resources (HR) Department:** This is typically the primary point of contact for harassment complaints. They are trained to handle such situations, investigate, and ensure appropriate action is taken.
    *   **Your Direct Manager/Supervisor:** If the colleague is not your direct manager, you can report it to your own manager. They have a responsibility to address workplace issues and can help facilitate a report to HR.
    *   **A More Senior Manager:** If your manager is the person making the comments, or if you don't feel comfortable reporting to them, go directly to HR or a more senior manager.
*   **What to Include in Your Report:**
    *   Clearly state that you are experiencing harassment from a colleague.
    *   Provide the documented evidence (screenshots, log of incidents).
    *   Explain the impact the comments are having on you (e.g., making you feel uncomfortable, anxious, unsafe at work).
    *   State what resolution you are seeking (e.g., for the behavior to stop, for the company to investigate and take appropriate disciplinary action, for measures to ensure your safety at work).
*   **What to Expect:**
    *   An investigation will likely be initiated.
    *   HR should keep you informed (to a reasonable extent, respecting privacy laws) about the process.
    *   They should take steps to ensure your safety and prevent further harassment, which might include separating you from the colleague, issuing a warning, or taking disciplinary action up to termination.
    *   You can request confidentiality, but be aware that complete anonymity may not always be possible during an investigation, as the accused has a right to know the nature of the allegations. However, HR should strive to protect your privacy as much as possible.

**Option 2: Informal Approach (Use with Extreme Caution)**

*   **Directly Asking Them to Stop (Not Always Recommended):** While sometimes a direct, firm conversation can resolve issues, *I strongly advise against this if you feel unsafe, intimidated, or if the comments are overtly sexual or threatening*. In these situations, a formal report is much safer and more effective.
    *   If you *do* consider this (e.g., if the comments were borderline and you genuinely believe they might not realize the impact), approach it with extreme caution. You could send a single, clear message (not on WhatsApp, as you've blocked them, but perhaps via work email if necessary) stating: "Your comments on [date/time] were inappropriate and made me uncomfortable. Please do not contact me outside of work-related matters, and keep all future communication professional."
    *   **Crucially, if you take this route, still document it.** Keep a copy of your message and their response (or lack thereof). If the behavior continues, you will still need to proceed with a formal report.

**Option 3: Legal Avenues (If Company Fails or Not Applicable)**

*   **Consult an Attorney:** If your company fails to address the situation adequately, or if you feel the harassment is severe enough to warrant legal action, you can consult an employment lawyer. They can advise you on your rights and potential legal remedies.
*   **Police (If Threats or Physical Safety Concerns):** If the messages contain any threats of physical harm, stalking, or make you fear for your physical safety, you should contact law enforcement immediately. This is separate from workplace reporting and concerns your personal safety.

### Self-Care and Support

This kind of experience can be incredibly draining emotionally.

*   **Lean on Your Support System:** Talk to your trusted friends, family, or a therapist.
*   **Prioritize Your Mental Health:** Take breaks, engage in activities you enjoy, and practice self-care to cope with the stress.
*   **Remember It's Not Your Fault:** Harassment is never the victim's fault. You are not responsible for someone else's inappropriate behavior.

Please take these steps carefully, and remember that you have the right to a safe and respectful environment. Your well-being is paramount.

prompt_text: Hey, mera ek colleague hai, woh WhatsApp pe inappropriate comments kar raha hai. Mujhe kya karna chahiye? I feel really uncomfortable.
model_response:
Hey, main samajh sakta hoon ki yeh kitna uncomfortable aur pareshaan karne wala ho sakta hai. Koi bhi workplace mein ya workplace se related communication mein inappropriate comments deserve nahi karta. Tumhara comfort aur safety sabse pehle hai.

Yahaan kuch practical steps hain jo tum le sakte ho:

1.  **Sabse Pehle, Apne Aap Ko Protect Karo:**
    *   **Screenshots Le Lo:** Jo bhi inappropriate comments aaye hain, unke screenshots le lo. Date aur time bhi clearly visible hona chahiye. Yeh future mein proof ka kaam karega.
    *   **Baat Na Badhao (Agar Comfortable Nahi Ho):** Agar tum direct confrontation mein comfortable nahi ho, toh usse seedha jawab mat do ya discussion mein mat ghuso. Tumhari safety aur mental peace zyada important hai.

2.  **Directly Bolne Ki Socho (Agar Comfortable Ho):**
    *   Agar tum comfortable ho aur sochti ho ki woh colleague shayad anjaane mein kar raha hai ya samajh jayega, toh tum usse personally ya chat par politely bol sakti ho ki "Mujhe yeh comments comfortable nahi lag rahe, please aise messages mat bhejo." Lekin, yeh tabhi karo jab tumhe lage ki yeh safe aur effective hoga.

3.  **Apne Manager Ya HR Se Baat Karo:**
    *   **Yeh Sabse Important Step Hai.** Agar tumhe direct bolne mein darr lag raha hai, ya tumne bola aur usne ignore kiya, toh bina der kiye apne Manager (agar woh bhi involved nahi hai) ya HR Department se baat karo.
    *   **Kya Bolna Hai:** Unhe saari baat batao, ki tumhara colleague WhatsApp par inappropriate comments kar raha hai aur tumhe isse bahut uncomfortable feel ho raha hai. Woh screenshots jo tumne liye hain, woh unhe dikhao.
    *   **Workplace Harassment Policy:** Har company ki ek anti-harassment policy hoti hai. Yeh workplace harassment ke under aata hai aur company ki responsibility hai ki woh is par action le.

4.  **WhatsApp Settings Adjust Karo:**
    *   Agar woh comments personal chat mein kar raha hai, toh tum uski chat ko mute kar sakti ho ya block bhi kar sakti ho, lakin yeh tabhi karo jab usse work communication disturb na ho. Agar group work-related hai toh block karna thoda mushkil ho sakta hai.

**Yaad Rakho:** Tumhe is situation ko akele handle karne ki zaroorat nahi hai. Tumhe uncomfortable feel karana galat hai, aur company ki duty hai ki woh ek safe aur respectful environment maintain kare. Apne liye khade hona aur sahi authorities ko inform karna bilkul theek hai.

Darrne ki koi baat nahi hai. Apne HR se contact karo aur unhe saari details do.

prompt_text: Hey chatbot, mujhe ek problem hai. Mera ek colleague WhatsApp pe mujhe inappropriate comments kar raha hai. Ab main kya karoon? Mujhe bahut gussa aa raha hai aur samajh nahi aa raha hai ki kya karna chahiye.
model_response:
अरे यार, यह तो बहुत ही गलत और परेशान करने वाली बात है! मुझे समझ आ रहा है कि तुम्हें कितना गुस्सा और परेशानी हो रही होगी। ऐसी हरकतें बिल्कुल बर्दाश्त नहीं की जा सकतीं, और यह तुम्हारी गलती बिल्कुल नहीं है।

देखो, अभी गुस्से में कुछ भी करने से पहले, कुछ ज़रूरी कदम उठाने होंगे। यह तुम्हारी सुरक्षा और भविष्य के लिए बहुत अहम है:

1.  **सबूत इकट्ठा करो (Screenshots):** सबसे पहले और सबसे ज़रूरी काम यह है कि तुम्हें जो भी इनएप्रोप्रियेट मैसेज आए हैं, उन सबके **स्क्रीनशॉट** ले लो। एक-एक मैसेज का स्क्रीनशॉट लो, जिसमें भेजने वाले का नाम/नंबर और मैसेज का समय भी दिखे। यह बहुत ज़रूरी सबूत है। इसे किसी सुरक्षित जगह पर सेव कर लो।

2.  **उसे तुरंत ब्लॉक करो:** स्क्रीनशॉट लेने के बाद, उस सहकर्मी को WhatsApp पर **तुरंत ब्लॉक कर दो**। उससे अब कोई बात मत करना और न ही उसके मैसेज का जवाब देना। उसका तुमसे संपर्क करने का रास्ता बंद कर दो।

3.  **कंपनी की पॉलिसी देखो:** तुम्हारी कंपनी में यौन उत्पीड़न (sexual harassment) या गलत व्यवहार से जुड़ी कोई पॉलिसी (नीति) ज़रूर होगी। उसे ढूंढो और ध्यान से पढ़ो। उसमें बताया होगा कि ऐसे मामलों में किसे रिपोर्ट करना है और क्या प्रक्रिया अपनानी है।

4.  **HR या मैनेजर से बात करो:** अपनी कंपनी के HR (ह्यूमन रिसोर्स) डिपार्टमेंट से या अपने सीधे मैनेजर (अगर वे भरोसेमंद हों और तुम्हें लगता है कि वे तुम्हारी मदद करेंगे) से बात करो। उन्हें पूरी बात बताओ और सारे स्क्रीनशॉट दिखाओ।

5.  **औपचारिक शिकायत दर्ज करो:** एक औपचारिक (formal) लिखित शिकायत दर्ज करो। इसमें घटना की तारीख, समय, मैसेज और तुमने क्या महसूस किया, सब कुछ विस्तार से लिखो। शिकायत में सबूत के तौर पर स्क्रीनशॉट भी संलग्न करो। इसकी एक कॉपी अपने पास भी रखना। अगर तुम्हारी कंपनी में 'आंतरिक शिकायत समिति' (Internal Complaints Committee - ICC) है, तो उनसे संपर्क करो। यह विशेष रूप से ऐसे मामलों को संभालने के लिए बनी होती है।

6.  **किसी भरोसेमंद व्यक्ति से बात करो:** यह सब बहुत तनावपूर्ण हो सकता है। इसलिए किसी भरोसेमंद दोस्त, परिवार के सदस्य या मेंटर से बात करो। वे तुम्हें भावनात्मक सहारा दे सकते हैं।

याद रखना, इसमें तुम्हारी कोई गलती नहीं है। तुम्हें एक सुरक्षित और सम्मानजनक माहौल में काम करने का पूरा अधिकार है। ये कदम तुम्हें इस स्थिति से निपटने में मदद करेंगे और तुम्हारी सुरक्षा सुनिश्चित करेंगे। हिम्मत रखो, तुम अकेली नहीं हो!

prompt_text:
Okay, here's the prompt, keeping in mind the instructions:

I am a guy, and I need to write a formal notice period letter for resigning from my job. Please provide a template or examples I can adapt for a two-week notice, ensuring it's polite and professional.
model_response:
Alright, fella, got it. Resigning can be a bit of a process, but you want to do it right – keep things clean, professional, and protect your future references. Think of this as your "safety-first" guide to getting that notice period letter done.

The key here is clarity, politeness, and adherence to your company's policy (usually outlined in your contract or employee handbook – always worth a quick check, just to be sure). For a two-week notice, you want to be precise about your last day.

Here's a solid template you can adapt. Just fill in the brackets with your specific details.

---

**Formal Resignation Letter Template (Two-Week Notice)**

[Your Name]
[Your Address]
[Your Phone Number]
[Your Email Address]

[Date]

[Hiring Manager Name] (or "Human Resources Department" if you're not sure who to address directly)
[Hiring Manager Title]
[Company Name]
[Company Address]

**Subject: Resignation – [Your Name]**

Dear [Mr./Ms./Mx. Last Name of Manager, or "Hiring Manager"],

Please accept this letter as formal notification that I am resigning from my position as [Your Position] at [Company Name]. My last day of employment will be two weeks from today, [Your Last Day of Employment – *calculate this carefully, e.g., if you submit on a Monday, your last day will be two Fridays later*].

I want to express my appreciation for the opportunities I have been provided during my time here. I am committed to ensuring a smooth transition during my remaining time and am happy to assist in training my replacement and completing any outstanding tasks to the best of my ability.

I wish you and [Company Name] all the best in the future.

Sincerely,

[Your Signature (if submitting a physical copy)]

[Your Typed Name]

---

**Practical, Safety-First Tips for You:**

1.  **Double-Check Your Contract/Handbook:** Seriously, this is your first line of defense. Just confirm that a two-week notice is indeed what's required. Some roles or companies might have longer periods. You don't want any surprises.
2.  **Calculate Your Last Day Precisely:** "Two weeks from today" can sometimes be ambiguous. Make sure the date you put in the letter is the exact day you intend to finish. If you hand it in on a Monday, your last day will typically be two Fridays later.
3.  **Deliver It Properly:**
    *   **Email is common:** Send it to your direct manager and CC Human Resources (HR). This creates a digital record.
    *   **Hard copy (optional but good practice):** Print it out, sign it, and hand it to your manager in person. You can even ask them to sign a copy for your records acknowledging receipt.
    *   **Confirm Receipt:** A polite follow-up if you don't hear back within a day.
4.  **Keep a Copy:** For your own records, always keep a copy of the letter you submitted.
5.  **Be Prepared for a Chat:** Your manager will likely want to meet with you after receiving the letter. Be ready to discuss your reasons (though you don't have to go into exhaustive detail), your transition plan, and any questions they might have.
6.  **Keep it Professional:** Even if you're unhappy, this letter is about maintaining a good relationship and not burning bridges. You never know when you might need a reference down the line. Keep it concise and to the point.
7.  **Consider Your Vacation/PTO:** If you have remaining vacation time, understand how your company handles it during a notice period. Some might let you take it, others might pay it out.

Stick to this, and you'll navigate your resignation like a pro, keeping your professional reputation intact. Good luck with the next chapter!

prompt_text:
Okay, here's the prompt:

I am a woman and need to write a professional notice period letter. Can you help me draft a polite letter for a two-week notice period, ensuring it's appropriate for a formal work environment?
model_response:
Absolutely, I can certainly help you with that! Crafting a professional and polite notice period letter is a thoughtful step in any career transition, and it's wonderful you're approaching it with such care.

Here's a draft for a two-week notice letter, designed to be clear, concise, and appropriate for a formal work environment. I'll also add some practical, safety-first tips to ensure a smooth departure.

---

### **Your Two-Week Notice Letter Draft**

[Your Name]
[Your Address]
[Your Phone Number]
[Your Email]

[Date]

[Hiring Manager Name] (or your direct Manager's Name)
[Hiring Manager Title]
[Company Name]
[Company Address]

**Subject: Resignation – [Your Name]**

Dear [Mr./Ms./Mx. Last Name of Manager],

Please accept this letter as formal notification that I am resigning from my position as [Your Position Title] at [Company Name]. My last day of employment will be two weeks from today, [Your Last Day of Employment – Date].

I want to express my sincere gratitude for the opportunity to have worked at [Company Name] for the past [Number] years/months. I have valued my time here and appreciate the experience I've gained in [mention a positive experience or skill, e.g., "developing my skills in project management" or "working with such a dedicated team"].

During my remaining time, I am committed to ensuring a smooth transition of my responsibilities. Please let me know how I can best assist in training my replacement and completing any outstanding tasks.

I wish [Company Name] all the best for the future.

Sincerely,

[Your Signature (if printing)]

[Your Typed Name]

---

### **Practical, Safety-First Guidance for Your Notice Period:**

1.  **Check Your Contract/Employee Handbook:** Before you send anything, quickly review your employment contract or company handbook. Just double-check if there are any specific requirements for notice periods (e.g., some roles might require more than two weeks, though two weeks is standard). This is your first safety net!

2.  **Inform Your Manager First (Verbally, if Possible):** Ideally, you'd have a brief, private conversation with your direct manager *before* sending the formal letter. This allows them to hear it from you directly, which is always more professional and considerate. You can say something like, "I'd like to schedule a quick chat with you today, as I have something important to discuss regarding my employment."

3.  **Delivery Method:**
    *   **Email (with attachment):** This is often the most practical. Send the letter as a PDF attachment to your manager, and cc HR if that's standard practice at your company. The subject line "Resignation – [Your Name]" is clear and unambiguous.
    *   **Hard Copy:** If your workplace is very traditional, you might print and sign a copy to hand to your manager, perhaps followed up with an email for record-keeping.
    *   **Keep a Copy:** Always keep a copy of the sent letter (and email) for your personal records.

4.  **Be Prepared for Questions:** Your manager might ask why you're leaving. You don't need to go into great detail. A simple, "I've accepted another opportunity that aligns with my career goals," or "I'm looking for a new challenge," is perfectly sufficient and professional. Avoid negativity about your current role or colleagues.

5.  **Focus on a Smooth Transition:** The offer to assist with training and handover is crucial. During your notice period, dedicate yourself to documenting your processes, organizing your files, and helping your colleagues understand your ongoing projects. Leaving things in excellent order reflects incredibly well on you.

6.  **Maintain Professionalism:** Even though you're leaving, continue to perform your duties to the best of your ability until your very last hour. Your professional reputation is long-lasting, and you want to leave a positive final impression.

7.  **Personal Files & Information:** Before your last day, make sure you've backed up any personal contacts, files, or information you might have stored on your work computer or email that you'll need. However, *never* take company proprietary information or client lists. Be very clear about what belongs to you versus what belongs to the company.

8.  **Final Paycheck & Benefits:** Understand how your final paycheck will be handled, including any accrued but unused vacation time. HR can provide clarity on this.

Taking these steps will help you depart gracefully and professionally, leaving the door open for future networking and positive references. Good luck with your next chapter!

prompt_text: Please draft a polite notice period letter for me, keeping the standard two-week timeframe in mind. I need to inform my employer about my departure.
model_response:
Of course, I can certainly help you draft a polite notice period letter. It's a thoughtful and professional step to take.

Here’s a draft you can adapt, keeping that standard two-week timeframe in mind:

---

**[Your Name]**
**[Your Address]**
**[Your Phone Number]**
**[Your Email]**

**[Date]**

**[Hiring Manager Name]** (or "Human Resources Department" if you're sending it there)
**[Hiring Manager Title]**
**[Company Name]**
**[Company Address]**

Dear **[Mr./Ms./Mx. Last Name of Manager]**,

Please accept this letter as formal notification that I am resigning from my position as **[Your Position]** at **[Company Name]**. My last day of employment will be two weeks from today, **[Your Last Day of Employment - e.g., Date two weeks from the letter date]**.

I want to express my sincere gratitude for the opportunity to have worked at **[Company Name]** for the past **[Number] years/months**. I have truly valued my time here and appreciate the experience and professional development I've gained.

During this transition, I am committed to ensuring a smooth handover of my responsibilities. I am happy to assist in training my replacement and completing any outstanding tasks to the best of my ability before my departure.

I wish you and **[Company Name]** all the best for the future.

Sincerely,

**[Your Name]**

---

**A few practical, safety-first thoughts for you as you prepare to send this:**

1.  **Check Your Contract:** Before you send this, it's always a good idea to quickly check your employment contract or company policy. While two weeks is very common, some roles or agreements might have a slightly different notice period. It's best to be sure!
2.  **Delivery Method:** Consider delivering this letter in person to your direct manager, and perhaps also sending a copy to Human Resources. It's wise to keep a copy for your own records, too. A follow-up email with the letter attached can also be a good way to ensure it's formally received.
3.  **Maintain Professionalism:** During your notice period, maintaining your professional demeanor and productivity is really important. It helps leave a positive lasting impression, which is invaluable for future references.
4.  **Final Details:** You might also want to connect with HR to discuss details regarding your final paycheck, any accrued vacation time, and benefits.

Wishing you all the very best with your next steps!

prompt_text: Bhai, mujhe ek polite notice period letter likhna hai, woh bhi do weeks ka. Kaise shuru karun aur kya-kya daalun? Thoda help kar de yaar!
model_response:
हाँ भाई, बिलकुल मदद करता हूँ! तू बिल्कुल सही सोच रहा है, एक polite notice period letter लिखना बहुत ज़रूरी है। इससे प्रोफेशनल इमेज अच्छी रहती है और आगे भी काम आ सकता है।

चल, मैं तुझे बताता हूँ कि कैसे शुरू करना है और क्या-क्या बातें डालनी हैं ताकि सब कुछ बढ़िया से हो जाए।

**सबसे पहले, ये कुछ बातें ध्यान रखियो:**

1.  **Date:** जिस दिन लेटर दे रहा है, वो तारीख।
2.  **Recipient:** किसे भेजना है? आमतौर पर ये तेरे मैनेजर या HR डिपार्टमेंट को होता है।
3.  **Notice Period:** तूने दो हफ्ते का बोला है, तो वो क्लियरली मेंशन करना है।

**लेटर का ढाँचा (Format) क्या होगा?**

**1. अपनी जानकारी (Your Details):**
*   तेरा नाम
*   तेरी पदवी (Designation)
*   तेरा कर्मचारी ID (अगर हो)
*   आज की तारीख

**2. प्राप्तकर्ता की जानकारी (Recipient's Details):**
*   [मैनेजर/HR मैनेजर का नाम] (अगर पता हो, वरना पदवी लिख दे)
*   [मैनेजर/HR मैनेजर की पदवी]
*   [कंपनी का नाम]
*   [कंपनी का पता]

**3. विषय (Subject Line):**
*   ये बहुत साफ़ और सीधा होना चाहिए।

**4. अभिवादन (Salutation):**
*   महोदय/महोदया (Sir/Madam)

**5. मुख्य भाग (Main Body):**
*   **पहला पैराग्राफ:** अपनी इस्तीफे की जानकारी दे और बता कि तू कितने समय का नोटिस दे रहा है। अपना अंतिम कार्य दिवस (Last Working Day) भी साफ-साफ बता दे।
*   **दूसरा पैराग्राफ (Optional, but good):** कंपनी में काम करने के अनुभव के लिए आभार व्यक्त कर।
*   **तीसरा पैराग्राफ:** बता कि तू इस ट्रांजीशन (transition) को आसान बनाने के लिए पूरी मदद करेगा/करेगी।

**6. समापन (Closing):**
*   "धन्यवाद" या "आपके सहयोग के लिए धन्यवाद।"
*   भवदीय (Sincerely)

**7. हस्ताक्षर (Signature):**
*   तेरा नाम

---

**ये ले भाई, एक नमूना (Sample Letter) जो तू इस्तेमाल कर सकता है:**

***

**[तेरा नाम]**
**[तेरी पदवी]**
**[तेरा कर्मचारी ID - अगर हो]**
**[तेरा ईमेल]**
**[तेरा फ़ोन नंबर]**

**[आज की तारीख]**

**सेवा में,**
**[मैनेजर/HR मैनेजर का नाम]** (अगर पता हो)
**[मैनेजर/HR मैनेजर की पदवी]**
**[कंपनी का नाम]**
**[कंपनी का पता]**

**विषय: त्यागपत्र एवं दो सप्ताह के नोटिस के संबंध में**

महोदय/महोदया,

मैं आपको सूचित करना चाहता/चाहती हूँ कि मैं [कंपनी का नाम] में अपनी [तेरी पदवी] के पद से त्यागपत्र दे रहा/रही हूँ। मेरा अंतिम कार्य दिवस **[आज की तारीख से ठीक दो हफ्ते बाद की तारीख]** होगा, जो कि मेरे दो सप्ताह के नोटिस पीरियड के अनुसार है।

मैं इस अवसर पर [कंपनी का नाम] में बिताए गए समय और मिले अनुभवों के लिए अपना हार्दिक आभार व्यक्त करना चाहता/चाहती हूँ। यहाँ काम करके मुझे बहुत कुछ सीखने और बढ़ने का मौका मिला।

मैं आपको विश्वास दिलाना चाहता/चाहती हूँ कि मैं अपने नोटिस पीरियड के दौरान अपने सभी लंबित कार्यों को पूरा करने और संक्रमण काल (transition period) को यथासंभव सहज बनाने के लिए हर संभव सहायता प्रदान करने को तैयार हूँ। कृपया मुझे बताएं कि इस प्रक्रिया में मैं किस प्रकार सहायता कर सकता/सकती हूँ।

आपके सहयोग के लिए धन्यवाद।

भवदीय,

**(तेरा हस्ताक्षर)**
**[तेरा पूरा नाम]**

***

**कुछ ज़रूरी बातें जिन पर ध्यान रखना है (Safety-First Tips):**

*   **कंपनी की पॉलिसी चेक कर ले:** एक बार अपनी कंपनी की HR पॉलिसी ज़रूर देख लेना कि उनका स्टैंडर्ड नोटिस पीरियड क्या है। अगर वो दो हफ्ते से ज़्यादा है और तू सिर्फ दो हफ्ते दे रहा है, तो HR से बात कर लेना।
*   **कॉपी रख ले:** लेटर की एक कॉपी अपने पास ज़रूर रखना, और अगर ईमेल से भेज रहा है तो सेंड ईमेल का रिकॉर्ड रखना।
*   **प्रोफेशनल रहना:** नोटिस पीरियड के दौरान भी अपना काम पूरी ईमानदारी और प्रोफेशनलिज्म से करना। कोई भी बात खराब करके मत जाना।
*   **जबान पर काबू:** भले ही तेरा जाने का मन हो, लेकिन किसी से कोई नकारात्मक बात मत कहना। हमेशा पॉजिटिव रहना।
*   **सही चैनल से भेज:** लेटर या तो अपने मैनेजर को हाथ से दे (और उनसे एक रिसीव्ड कॉपी पर साइन ले ले) या फिर कंपनी के ऑफिशियल ईमेल ID पर भेज।

बस भाई, ये सब बातें ध्यान रखियो और तेरा लेटर एकदम परफेक्ट बनेगा। कोई और मदद चाहिए हो तो बताना!

prompt_text: Mujhe ek polite notice period letter likhna hai, woh bhi two weeks ka. Iske liye kya format hona chahiye aur kaise shuru karun? Mujhe help karo!
model_response:
नमस्ते! बिल्कुल, मैं आपकी मदद करता हूँ। दो हफ़्तों का नोटिस पीरियड देने के लिए एक पोलाइट और प्रोफेशनल रेजिग्नेशन लेटर लिखना बहुत ज़रूरी है। यह आपके और कंपनी के बीच एक अच्छा संबंध बनाए रखने में मदद करता है।

यहाँ एक बढ़िया फॉर्मेट है और कुछ बातें हैं जो आपको ध्यान रखनी चाहिए:

---

**लेटर का फॉर्मेट और शुरुआत कैसे करें:**

1.  **आपकी जानकारी (Your Information):**
    *   आपका नाम
    *   आपका पता
    *   आपका फ़ोन नंबर
    *   आपकी ईमेल ID
    *   तारीख

2.  **कंपनी की जानकारी (Company Information):**
    *   HR मैनेजर का नाम (अगर पता हो) या सीधे "माननीय HR मैनेजर"
    *   कंपनी का नाम
    *   कंपनी का पता

3.  **विषय (Subject Line):**
    *   यह स्पष्ट और संक्षिप्त होना चाहिए।
    *   उदाहरण: **"इस्तीफे के संबंध में"** या **"रेजिग्नेशन लेटर"**

4.  **अभिवादन (Salutation):**
    *   माननीय HR मैनेजर / [मैनेजर का नाम],
    *   या सीधे: प्रिय [मैनेजर का नाम],

5.  **मुख्य पैराग्राफ (Main Paragraph - जहाँ आप इस्तीफा देते हैं):**
    *   यहाँ आप स्पष्ट रूप से बताते हैं कि आप इस्तीफा दे रहे हैं और अपनी अंतिम कार्य तिथि (Last Working Day) का उल्लेख करते हैं।
    *   उदाहरण: "मैं आपको सूचित करना चाहता हूँ कि मैं [कंपनी का नाम] में अपने [आपकी पदवी] के पद से इस्तीफा दे रहा हूँ। इस पत्र को मेरा दो सप्ताह का नोटिस मानें, और मेरी अंतिम कार्य तिथि [तारीख] होगी।"

6.  **धन्यवाद और सहयोग (Gratitude and Offer to Assist):**
    *   कंपनी में काम करने के अवसर के लिए धन्यवाद करें।
    *   संक्रमण काल (transition period) के दौरान सहयोग करने की इच्छा व्यक्त करें ताकि काम सुचारू रूप से चलता रहे।
    *   उदाहरण: "मैं [कंपनी का नाम] में काम करने के अवसर के लिए आभारी हूँ और मैंने यहाँ अपने कार्यकाल के दौरान बहुत कुछ सीखा है। मैं अपनी जिम्मेदारियों को सुचारू रूप से सौंपने के लिए संक्रमण काल के दौरान हर संभव सहायता प्रदान करने के लिए तैयार हूँ।"

7.  **शुभकामनाएं (Good Wishes):**
    *   कंपनी के भविष्य के लिए शुभकामनाएं दें।
    *   उदाहरण: "मैं कंपनी के उज्ज्वल भविष्य के लिए शुभकामनाएं देता हूँ।"

8.  **समापन (Closing):**
    *   भवदीय,
    *   या सादर,

9.  **आपका हस्ताक्षर और नाम (Your Signature and Name):**
    *   (आपका हस्ताक्षर)
    *   आपका पूरा नाम

---

**यहाँ एक पूरा ड्राफ्ट (उदाहरण) है जिसे आप इस्तेमाल कर सकते हैं:**

**[आपका नाम]**
**[आपका पता]**
**[आपका फ़ोन नंबर]**
**[आपकी ईमेल ID]**

**[तारीख]**

**माननीय HR मैनेजर / [आपके मैनेजर का नाम]**
**[कंपनी का नाम]**
**[कंपनी का पता]**

**विषय: इस्तीफे के संबंध में**

प्रिय [HR मैनेजर का नाम/मैनेजर का नाम],

मैं आपको सूचित करना चाहता हूँ कि मैं [कंपनी का नाम] में अपने [आपकी पदवी] के पद से इस्तीफा दे रहा हूँ। इस पत्र को मेरा दो सप्ताह का नोटिस मानें, और मेरी अंतिम कार्य तिथि [**आज से दो सप्ताह बाद की तारीख लिखें, जैसे 25 अगस्त, 2024**] होगी।

मैं [कंपनी का नाम] में काम करने के अवसर के लिए आभारी हूँ और मैंने यहाँ अपने कार्यकाल के दौरान बहुत कुछ सीखा है। मैं अपनी जिम्मेदारियों को सुचारू रूप से सौंपने के लिए संक्रमण काल के दौरान हर संभव सहायता प्रदान करने के लिए तैयार हूँ ताकि काम पर कोई असर न पड़े।

मैं कंपनी के उज्ज्वल भविष्य के लिए शुभकामनाएं देता हूँ।

सादर,

(आपका हस्ताक्षर)
**[आपका पूरा नाम]**

---

**कुछ ज़रूरी बातें (Safety-First Guidance):**

*   **अपनी एम्प्लॉयमेंट कॉन्ट्रैक्ट जांच लें:** सबसे पहले, अपने जॉब कॉन्ट्रैक्ट या कंपनी की HR पॉलिसी को ज़रूर चेक करें। कई बार कॉन्ट्रैक्ट में नोटिस पीरियड के बारे में स्पष्ट रूप से लिखा होता है। अगर आपका कॉन्ट्रैक्ट दो सप्ताह से ज़्यादा का नोटिस पीरियड मांगता है और आप सिर्फ दो सप्ताह देना चाहते हैं, तो एक बार HR से बात करना बेहतर होगा।
*   **प्रूफ ऑफ डिलीवरी:** अगर आप ईमेल से भेज रहे हैं, तो सुनिश्चित करें कि वह सही व्यक्ति तक पहुंचे। अगर हार्ड कॉपी दे रहे हैं, तो उसकी एक कॉपी अपने पास रखें और हो सके तो रिसीविंग पर हस्ताक्षर करवा लें।
